Comment: From Latin hospitium: late antique or earlier medieval borrowing, not attested in Classical texts but borrowed before the procope of unstressed vowels
Borrowed from Old French grif (13th century) from Old High German grifân with the development *skrif > skirf and dissimilation.
'dusted, sprinkled with dust, dusty'; Latin form given for structural reasons, mre likely a late loan from an Italian dialect
Early Romance *bodel, from Lat. botellus 'small sausage'
one parallel loan or loan into e.g. Persian and parallel loan from there?
Either from Old Norse or Swedish
Definite article analysed as part of the stem in the borrowed form.
Loanword presumably via English or French
A loanword of uncertain origin, cf. Breton sebon, German Seife.
denominative verb from the Old French noun chace 'hunt' (12th cent.)
probably borrowed before *rd > l (i.e. Old Persian)
The Turkish word is a borrowing from Persian, see cognate class http://cobl.info/cognate/718/.
Cf. Macedonian блато 'marsh, swamp, bog', cf. also Albanian baltë

May also be a loan from Proto-Germanic. Goidelic forms may be borrowed themselves from Brythonic.
Cf. Parthian wz- 'to move swiftly, fly; travel'; cf. Ved.váhati, etc.
or younger and < Old French tost?
‘burns’  T. 11097.1.  Loan because of ṣ, rather than s, after u.
Probable loanword, but of uncertain origin (cf. KEWA I:405-406 for further discussion).
from Old French roont (1155) < Latin rotundum
uncertain whether loan or inherited (or a mix?)
Early loanword event in Latin (already attested Ennius, late 3rd - early 2nd c. BCE).
The donor language surely is Persian, although this word is a loanword in Persian as well.
Possibly borrowed into Albanian from the Latin root 'crem' (burn) with prefix 'ex-'. with vowel change in Albanian.
Latin machināre is denominal to machina 'engine, mechanical device', a loanword from (Doric) Greek
A denominal verb based on a noun of Celtic origin, cf. von Wartburg, FEW 6/3:197 for further discussion.
A loanword from neighbouring Dardic languages, cf. Turner 1962–1966:637 s.v. 10991  *laṣṭi- 'stick'
Probable loanword from Dravidian, cf.  Tamil kaluḻ- 'become turbid', Kannada kaluhe 'dirt'
only attested in the compound asā dāru "stone wood i.e. ebony", as such a loanword with Central Iranic (aka. NWIr.) s, came probably together with the product
generally believed to be of Median origin
Latin lancea is certainly a loanword in origin, but it's precise origins are unclear (cf. Ernout & Meillet 1985:339-340).
A Balkan Wanderwort, cf. Albanian kopaç, Hungarian kopács.
It is sometimes claimed (cf. ESSJ) that the word is native (PS *but-).
Borrowed into Latin from Ancient Greek as a terminus technicus; acquired specialised meaning 'leg' only later in Romance.
Borrowed into Latin from Ancient Greek as a terminus technicus; acquired specialised meaning 'leg' only later in Romance.
Some uncertainty exists whether the Breton verb was borrowed directly from Old French conter, or a denominal formation within Breton based on a loanword from Old French conte (Deshayes 2003:413)
It is hard to determine precisely how and when the root arose in Ukrainian (it can be an old Common Slavic loanword but it also could pass to Ukrainian through Church Slavonic etc.).

Most probably the source was a folk form wonitować. The Polish source form is itself a loan from Latin. Polish wymiotować can not be the source of the Belarusian lexeme from phonetic reasons (it can be supposed that the Polish wymiotować is a folk etymology).

Either a direct borrowing from Old French lac, or a semantic borrowing from Old French lac, reinterpreting inherited material (cf. OE lacu 'small stream of running water' < Proto-Germanic *lak-, cf. OED, EWAhd)
Probable loanword from Dravidian, cf. Burrow & Emeneau 1984:139 for parallels.
Relatively late loanword from Lat (acc.sg.) canem or, rather, from its Balkan continuations, reflected in the lack of rhotacism in Tosk.
Borrowed < Lat capessere ~ capissere (inf.) 'to seize, snatch at', or < Rom. *capsare based on Lat capere 'to take'.
Loans from Middle Low German in turn from Medieval Latin spesa from Latin expensa (pecunia)
A verbal derivative from Greek γούλα 'throat, neck', a loanword from Latin gula 'throat, gullet'
Borrowed from Old French boute < bot 'blow, ' (1160), bouter 'to collide, to clash, to push' (1190).
In Pashto, the loan event must have taken place after inherited short *a was reduced and inherited OIr. *d > l.
variant of coffre (1175) from Vulgar Latin *cophinum of Greek origin
Generally considered from an Celtic borrowing in Latin (cf. Welsh peth).
